captions.text: Yesterday, I asked on Facebook what would you guys want to see
when it comes to Tokyo, on this youtube channel.
Many of you said you were interested in ordinary, day-to-day life in Japan
so today we'll show you a little bit of that.
Everyday life in Tokyo revolves around the underground system.
I need to top up my card now
This is how you do it, money, card. There you go.
Not exactly rocket science.
The card serves as your ticket, it's contactless, so quite a useful little thing
On every platform there's a schedule like this one, where you can check out the stations on each line
The one we're going to is right here
You can check how long it takes to get there as well
And the highlighted numbers indicate stations most convenient for changing to a different line
It tells you which train car to choose to make your transfer quickest
Those gates tell you the carriage and door number
Every time they stop exactly there
This board here breaks down all the destinations on a particular line
and the direction of trains from this platform, exact times for reaching each destination included
and all the stations for changing the line.
As far as clarity and usability go, it'd be difficult to top that
...And my personal favourite thing about it.
Nobody tries to force their way in, everyone waits patiently for the train to empty first
I mean - how difficult was that!
Is this where I say something smart?
A few years ago handhelds were THE hot thing on Tokyo underground
Today it's mostly smartphones.
Every station has got its very own theme tune.
We just got off the train and we want to change to the Yamanote overground line.
It's a no-brainer, everything is clearly marked, every exit on every station, all the transfer points.
We're at the Ikebukuro station right now, one of the three, I think, biggest stations in Tokyo
definitely somewhere among the biggest ones.
Well, you can see for yourselves just how hectic it is.
The nice thing is that underground and overground here are interconnected
You can change from one to the other and back as you please
That's a lot of mileage you can cover in one go.
And the distances here are overwhelming
Fortunately, you only touch in an out at the beginning and at the end of the entire journey,
and the system works out the quickest way you could've taken.
So if you mess up or space out and take a longer route, you're not going to pay more.
I mean there's an exception to this rule
when you change from overground to subway you do have to go through the ticket gates.
Anyway. Just ignore me.
We're on the Yamanote line, the line that circles central Tokyo
connecting all the important spots.
There's a train every 2-3 minutes
So it's not a tragedy if you miss one
you wouldn't start crying and try to chase it, as you normally do.
Notice how the doors arrive exactly in the spot they were supposed to
so people waiting for a train can form a neat queue.
We're not on the underground anymore, this is overground actually
works pretty much in the same way, only it's overground
It's crazy how flawlessly this whole system works
Nothing is ever late, everything is always on time
and I mean: within 5 seconds of the schedule kind of thing.
Everyone tries to keep their voice down when they talk on the train
talking on the phone on public transport is a serious breach of etiquette.
You stay quiet and don't disturb other passengers
We're passing Shinjuku right now, probably world's busiest station.
Because it all runs so smoothly and on such a massive scale
it doesn't make much sense to be driving in Tokyo
The only people who own cars are the ones really trying to show off.
Or the ones really into that sort of thing.
Or the families.
Everybody else takes the train, even rich people.
Because the system is so efficient...
Oh lookie here, a vending machine.
...because it's so efficient, when you look at the map of Tokyo
and get the impression something is really far away...
Me, being from Kraków, I feel like it's a long, long way between my side of town and the other.
And that transport takes forever.
Well, here the distance is 10 times as much
and it only takes 15 minutes or so.
People commute to Tokyo, wether it's to work or to party
from many miles away.
If you took two furthest points the Tokyo public transport operates on
I'm guessing the distance between them would be something like 150 km (over 90 miles).
So obviously, all the big stations in Tokyo are also huge shopping malls
There's plenty of food and entertainment.
People tend to spend quite a lot of time here daily, both on the underground and overground
and everything in between.
So there's a whole industry built around it.
It might seem busy, but it's not even the rush hour
the amount of people rushing through here is absurd.
But there's one myth we should probably bust
There are no 'pushers'.
You know, the ones everybody talks about.
I mean, apparently there are some, on particularly busy stations in the mornings
But I haven't ever seen them myself.
Another quick, handy... public transport tip.
For you guys.
You keep to the left.
When you walk that is, it's the left-hand traffic.
On the escalator though you stand on the left, and walk on the right if you're in hurry.
You've been asking me quite a lot about how easy or difficult
it is to get around Tokyo if you're not fluent in Japanese.
Well it all depends on what you're trying to explore, but at least on the underground
it's very difficult to get lost.
And of course we have here the women-only passenger cars, as well
usually located at the very front or the very end of the train
in the morning hours only ladies are allowed in
This is due to a big groping problem
on the overcrowded morning trains
some guys just can't keep their hands to themselves.
Trying to solve the issue, they decided to introduce those carriages.
There's many underground lines in Tokyo, operating on different levels
some of them as low as 40m (130ft) below the ground.
This escalator we are on looks like something from the set of Akira
And the stations themselves are huge,
changing from one line to another you have to walk half a mile sometimes.
Yeah, let's keep in minds it's all here
a shitload of lines, stations and everything
and it doesn't even cover the whole thing
you need all those overground lines as well, and there are 4 times as many of those.
And this is what a 30-million-people city looks like.
